results.title: Art of the hunter
results.brief_description: Shows Aborigines making weapons, hunting, cooking and painting on bark. Also shows some rare cave paintings. Filmed in the Northern Territory near Darwin.
results.description: Shows Aborigines making weapons, hunting, cooking and painting on bark. Also shows some rare cave paintings. Filmed in the Northern Territory near Darwin.

results.title: BabaKiueria = Barbeque area [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Atherden, Don Featherstone, Julian Pringle and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
‘BabaKiueria’ takes a satirical look at black-white relations in late twentieth century Australia, with a comic depiction of a racial role reversal. In documentary (or ‘mockumentary’) style, the film’s presenter investigates white lives in the fictitious land of ‘BabaKiueria’ (‘Barbeque Area’), where white people are a minority, living under black laws and suffering from discriminatory practices and attitudes held by the black majority. Written by Geoffrey Atherden (‘Mother and Son’, ‘Grass Roots’), the film was awarded a United Nations Media Peace Prize in 1987.
Stars Michelle Torres, Bob Maza, Kevin Smith, Cecily Polson, Tony Barry.

results.title: The Balanda and the bark canoes
results.creator_credit: Rolf De Heer, Tania Nehme, Molly Reynolds, Julie Ryan, SBS Independent and Fandango Australia
results.brief_description: Australian director Rolf de Heer has said of his multi-award winning feature film “Ten Canoes” “it is the most difficult film I have made, in the most foreign land I’ve been to…and it is Australia.” Narrated by de Heer, “The Balanda and the Bark Canoes” tells the story of the making of “Ten Canoes” on location in the Arafura Swamp of Central Arnhem Land. The difficulties of filming in a remote and crocodile infested location, in collaboration with members of the indigenous Yolngu community - many of whom have little or no English, and very different approaches to storytelling and film-making - are vividly, and often humorously, depicted. “The Balanda and the Bark Canoes” also shows us how some aspects of traditional Yolngu culture are rediscovered and renewed by the process of making the film, and the enduring positive effect the project has had on the Ramingining community. (Awards: 53rd Sydney Film Festival - Urban Cinefile Audience Award)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rolf De Heer, Tania Nehme, Molly Reynolds, Julie Ryan, SBS Independent and Fandango Australia

results.title: Constructing Australia
results.creator_credit: Alex West, Piper Films, Prospero Productions, Real Pictures and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The Sydney Harbour Bridge, the Kalgoorlie Pipeline and the Overland Telegraph were amongst Australia’s most significant civil engineering projects. “Constructing Australia” is a series of three films - “The Bridge”, “Pipe Dreams” and “A Wire Through the Heart” - that tells the story behind these landmarks in the construction of white Australian society. Combining dramatic re-enactments with archival footage, documentary sources, and interviews, the three films deal not only with the practical challenges and problems that faced each of the projects, but also reveal the personal triumphs and tragedies, the political intrigues, the human dramas and the social contexts behind these pioneering events.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alex West, Piper Films, Prospero Productions, Real Pictures and Film Australia

results.title: Nice coloured girls [DVD]
results.brief_description: Nice Coloured Girls uses experimental film techniques in an examination of the new urban ritual of taking white men for a ride. No longer the victims of these men, the women are still trapped by economic necessity. “Nice Coloured Girls” uses a clever juxtaposition of images and voice over of extracts from early journals of white settlers to compare aspects of the relationship between Aboriginal women and white men in the past and in the 1980s. Cast includes Gayle Mabo, Cheryl Pit, Janelle Court, Fiona George and Lindsay McCorrmack. (Awards: London, Berlin, Toronto)

results.title: Women of the sun: 25 years later
results.creator_credit: Bob Weis, Julie Andrews and Generation Films
results.brief_description: The impact of the landmark 1981 Australian television drama series “Women of the Sun” on its audience was profound. Groundbreaking in its attempts to present stories of Aboriginal Australian women from their own perspectives and in their own languages, the series won the United Nations Media Peace Prize. In this moving documentary, Bob Weis - the producer of the series - explores the effects “Women of the Sun” has had on the lives of some of those involved with its making. Weis interviews some of the people who acted in the series - Justine Saunders, Shirley Nirrpurrangyydji, Naykalan Mununggur, Michelle LaCombe and Eva Johnson - as well as series co-writer Sonia Borg, and indigenous academic Marcia Langton. The film also features remarkable archival footage of series co-writer, poet and educator Hyllus Maris.

results.title: Knot at home project: disc two
results.creator_credit: Phillip Crawford, BIG hART, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: The eight films included in the two Knot at Home titles are the result of a series of community projects run by BIG hART, a non profit community organisation. The projects were designed to give people who often go unheard a chance to tell their stories. From 1998 to 2004 over five hundred young people were asked to tell stories about when they felt “not at home”. The “Knot at Home” films present their stories using interviews, narratives, vignettes, songs, animations, dramatised scenes and memories. The young storytellers have made the films themselves, mentored by experienced filmmakers. Contents of “Knot at Home Disc Two” are: Program Five, “Stories of my Family”; Program Six, “Stories of Loyalty” (short film sequences directed by Nathan Brown and Phillip Crawford); Program Seven, “Stories of Insight”; and Program Eight, “Stories About Telling my Story” (short film sequences directed by Rachel Ward). Disc One [319750].

results.title: The Tracker [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Rolf De Heer, Julie Ryan, South Australian Film Corporation and Vertigo Productions
results.brief_description: Set in the Australian outback in 1922 and filmed on location in the Flinders Ranges, South Australia, “The Tracker” tells the story of three white men and an indigenous tracker in pursuit of a fugitive. The Tracker (David Gulpilil) is a native policeman during a time in which trackers were employed to find suspects. He answers to The Fanatic (Gary Sweet), a cruel bigot who is hell bent on catching The Fugitive, an aboriginal man accused of murdering a white woman. The Follower (Damon Gameau), is a naive young colonial policeman new to the job while The Veteran (Grant Page) is a world weary man whose kind nature is overridden by what he must do and how society expects him to treat blacks. The three white men are ultimately dependent on the silent, ever watchful tracker. When an interrogation of some bush blacks turns into a massacre, the balance of power shifts and assumed notions of truth and justice are thrown into question. While the film tackles the brutal treatment of Aborigines by white police, De Heer averts a realist portrayal of graphic violence by cutting to paintings (by South Australian artist, Peter Coad) that represent the scenes of brutality and bloodshed. With its sparse use of dialogue, but much of the film’s thematic content - about the displacement of Aboriginal peoples by white settlers, and conflict between white and indigenous systems of justice - is conveyed through songs written by Graham Tardif and performed for the film by indigenous musician, Archie Roach. David Gulpilil won an AFI Award for best actor for his role in the film. Written by Rolf de Heer ; cinematography by Ian Jones ; editing by Tania Nehme. Jointly commissioned by Adelaide Festival of the Arts 2002 and SBS Independent. Also available on VHS [317684].
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rolf De Heer, Julie Ryan, South Australian Film Corporation and Vertigo Productions

results.title: Homemade history
results.creator_credit: Robert Herbert, Sophie Jackson, SBS Independent, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Australian Film Commission and Arcadia Pictures
results.brief_description: A delightful slice of Australian life, this compilation of home made short films shot on 8mm film are sure to bring back memories or inspire new filmmakers. Memories of everyday life, beach holidays, careers, travel, weddings, music and fashion. Thirteen home movie filmmakers narrate a five minute edited version of their films dating from the 1930s to the 1980s, each ending with a contemporary portrait of the people involved. Aboriginal families, immigrant families, gay and lesbian protest movement and our first Paralympics team are some of the more fascinating works. Seeing a home movie shot in the 1930s and narrated by the filmmaker (the late Les Petty) is simply captivating.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Herbert, Sophie Jackson, SBS Independent, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Australian Film Commission and Arcadia Pictures
results.description: A delightful slice of Australian life, this compilation of home made short films shot on 8mm film are sure to bring back memories or inspire new filmmakers. Memories of everyday life, beach holidays, careers, travel, weddings, music and fashion. Thirteen home movie filmmakers narrate a five minute edited version of their films dating from the 1930s to the 1980s, each ending with a contemporary portrait of the people involved. Aboriginal families, immigrant families, gay and lesbian protest movement and our first Paralympics team are some of the more fascinating works. Seeing a home movie shot in the 1930s and narrated by the filmmaker (the late Les Petty) is simply captivating.
